I should follow Rich's example, and explain my reasoning.  The obvious choices are Kanayama & Owari.  The melted iron surface, small size, & tekotsu in the rim all argue for Kanayama, and similar tsuba are often found just so classified.  But Kanayama tsuba are more prone to difficult to identify motifs than Owari, and none of the characteristics here exclude Owari.  So I thought it better to bet on the dark horse choice. 

----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Jim Gilbert 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Saturday, March 04, 2006 6:52 PM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kantei


  We have two offline bids from people who saw the guard on exhibition in Tampa in addition to David and Richard's judgments.  Anyone still working on a bid?

  I won't give the setsumei tonight (EST) in any event.

  Jim



    OK, here is a guard for kantei:

    http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/2964?c

    77.0 mm H x 74.8 mm W, 7.2 mm thick at the mimi and 7.1 mm thick at the seppa dai.


    As far as I know it has not been published, but it has been exhibited at a couple of study meetings.  So, if you've already seen it and remember the attribution, please don't post the answer to the list.  It is mumei and there are two almost equally reasonable attributions, but I think that there is more evidence for one than the other.

    Respond with your bid on or off list as you prefer.

    Jim
